Luo and N. Zhang contributed equally to this work. Creating structure defects in ceria-based solid solution catalysts is a crucial yet challenging task. Herein, urea-assisted synthesis strategy was designed for ceria-zirconia-praseodymia catalyst (CeZrPrOx) to create lattice defects; its effects on catalyst structure, physical-chemical properties and catalytic diesel soot purification activity were systematically investigated. Raman and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) findings indicate that the urea-assisted synthesized catalyst (CeZrPrOx-U) has remarkably more Ce3+ proportion (structure defects), oxygen vacancies and surface reactive oxygen species (O2 2- and O2-). Temperature-programmed reduction by hydrogen (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption by oxygen (O2-TPD) results further prove that the oxygen migration of the CeZrPrOx-U is definitely enhanced. Compared to the conventional CeZrPrOx catalyst, the bulk lattice oxygen of the CeZrPrOx-U can be migrated to the surface to generate surface reactive oxygen species more easily. As a consequence, the prepared CeZrPrOx-U catalyst exhibits obviously better catalytic diesel soot purification activity. Therefore, this study suggests that engineering the structure defects in CeZrPrOx catalyst is an effective approach to improve physical-chemical properties and enhance the soot catalytic elimination activity of the catalyst. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ceria-based solid solution Lattice defects Soot combustion Automotive exhaust catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Because of the superior fuel efficiency, power output and robustness, diesel engine has gained significant attention in transportation and heavy equipment [1,2]. However, diesel engine exhaust is the principle source of urban air pollution through its emissions of particular matter (PM, mainly is soot), NO x , HC and CO etc. [3-5]. Particularly, the majority of PM emitted by diesel vehicles falls within the size range of 0.02–0.5 μm. Numerous studies have found that PM2.5 exposure is strongly linked to cardiovascular and respiratory disease [6]. Furthermore, soot from diesel exhaust interacts with gaseous pollutants and then forms a more hazardous mixture that poses detrimental effects on the heart and lungs, surpassing the harm caused by soot particles alone [7]. Catalytic Diesel Particulate Filter (CDPF) is a highly efficient device in minimizing the emission of soot from diesel engines [8,9]. The filter devices consist of functionalized ceramic monoliths and metallic alloys such as FeCrAl-based filters [10]. The CDPF device filters and traps soot to eliminate particulate matter in diesel exhaust, and then burns the trapped soot to complete the regeneration of CDPF [11-13]. However, ignition temperature of soot particle is generally above 500 °C, while the diesel exhaust temperature is generally lower than 450 °C. Therefore, coating CDPF with a high-performance catalyst to reduce the ignition temperature of soot is particularly important [4,14,15]. Currently, CeO2 has gained significant attention as a catalyst for diesel soot purification because of its remarkable oxygen storage and release capacity [11,16], excellent redox properties [17,18] and unique Ce4+/Ce3+ redox pair [19]. Besides that, special morphology (such as nanorods [20,21], nanoparticles [22], nanofibers [23], three-dimensional ordered macroporous [24], micron-sized macropores [25] etc.), highly active exposed crystalline surfaces [26] and metal modifications (rare earth metals [1,27], transition metals [28], noble metals [29] etc.) have been considered as effective means to enhance the catalytic activity of CeO2-based catalysts for soot oxidation. For metal modification of CeO2, the introduction of zirconium can remarkably improve the redox properties, oxygen storage/release ability and the oxygen mobility of CeO2 catalyst [30]. Moreover, the addition of praseodymium can raise the reactive oxygen concentration of the catalyst and promote the formation of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst [27,31,32]. However, catalytic elimination of diesel soot by ceria-based catalysts under low-temperature is still a challenging issue. The enhancement of oxygen mobility that can improve the migration of reactive oxygen species from catalyst lattice to surface may be an effective method. Considering all of this, the structure defects and oxygen migration of CeZrPrOx solid solution catalyst was designed through a urea-assisted synthesis strategy. The influence of urea-assisted synthesis on CeZrPrOx catalyst defect structure, physico-chemical properties and its soot catalytic elimination activity were investigated in this work. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All reagents are obtained from a commercial source and are ready to use without purification. Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Pr(NO3)3·6H2O and Zr(NO3)4·5H2O are chemically pure. Urea, ammonia solution and hydrogen peroxide are analytically pure. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The CeZrPrOx catalyst with theoretical composition of Ce0.4Zr0.5Pr0.1Ox was prepared as follows. The cerium nitrate, zirconium nitrate and praseodymium nitrate were weighed as 11.75 g, 13.31 g and 2.94 g, respectively; and dissolved in ultrapure water with 7 ml of hydrogen peroxide. The solution was co-precipitated with ammonia solution at 40 °C, the pH was maintained at 7–8 by the addition volume of ammonia solution. After co-precipitation, 4 g of urea was added and stirred continuously for 3 h. Then keeping for 24 h at 160 °C in a stainless steel vessel lined with polytetrafluoroethylen, after that the mixture is centrifuged and washed 3 times, and the collected precipitates underwent 3 h of calcination in a muffle furnace at a temperature of 600 °C. Following the calcination process, the catalyst powder was obtained and marked as CeZrPrOx-U. Ce0.4Zr0.5Pr0.1Ox catalyst was synthesized by the traditionally industrial co-precipitation method and used as reference sample. 11.75 g of cerium nitrate, 13.31 g of zirconium nitrate and 2.94 g of praseodymium nitrate were dissolved in ultrapure water with 7 ml of hydrogen peroxide. The solution was then co-precipitated with ammonia solution at 40 °C, the pH was maintained at 7–8. After that the slurry was ripened, centrifuged and washed 3 times, the precipitates underwent 3 h of calcination in a muffle furnace at a temperature of 600 °C, and then the CeZrPrOx catalyst was obtained. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The morphology and nanostructure of the prepared catalysts were observed by transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20) and field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Zeiss MERLIN type). The X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) spectra of the catalysts were obtained using PANalytical X'Pert PRO MRD instrument with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å). The spectra were collected with a scanning step of 0.02° over a range of 2θ = 5°−80° Renishaw RM2000 laser Raman spectrometer was used to collect the Raman spectra with an excitation wavelength of 514 nm, and the spectral signals were recorded within the range of 100–4000 cm-1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was collected by using Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi spectrometer with monochromatic Al Kα as excitation. To ensure accurate calibration, all spectra were referenced to the Cls peak at 284.8 eV Temperature-programmed reduction by hydrogen (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption by oxygen (O2-TPD) analysis were performed on a dynamic adsorption analyzer. For the both tests, 100 mg of catalyst particles sieved with a grain size between 0.6 mm and 0.9 mm were used. For H2-TPR analysis, the catalyst was purged in an N2 atmosphere at 450 °C for 30 min and then cooled to room temperature; afterwards heated to 900 °C in a 5 vol% H2–95 vol% N2 atmosphere with 10 °C/min ramp rate. The signal was collected using thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For O2-TPD analysis, the catalyst was purged in He atmosphere at 450 °C for 30 min. Whereafter, the catalyst was cooled down to 80 °C and adsorbed in an oxygen atmosphere at 80 °C for 1 hour. Flowing cooled down to room temperature, catalysts were heated to 900 °C in a He atmosphere with 10 °C/min ramp rate, the desorbed oxygen signals were monitored with TCD. The textual properties of the catalysts were analyzed using a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 plus HD88 physical adsorption analyzer by N2 adsorption-desorption at 77 K. Prior to testing, the samples were underwent a vacuum pretreatment at 300 °C for 3 h Before the testing, the samples were put through a 3 h vacuum pretreatment at 300 °C. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) was utilized for calculating specific surface area, and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) was utilized for calculating pore size distribution. 2.4 Catalytic activity tests Temperature-programmed combustion (TPC) test was conducted in a laboratory fixed-bed reactor to assess the catalytic soot elimination activity of the prepared catalysts. The experimental samples were dried for 3 h at a constant temperature of 120 °C before the test. A loose contact mode was used in this experiment. The catalyst was mixed with soot at a mass ratio of catalyst to soot of 9:1. The samples of the soot/catalyst mixture were prepared by mixing them with a medicine spoon for 1 min. About 100 mg of the appeal catalyst-soot amalgamation were positioned within a stainless steel tube under the gas blend comprising 10.0 vol% O2, 1000 ppm NO, 7.0 vol% H2O, and N2 balance. Then the stainless steel tube was heated to 750 °C with a increase rate of 2 °C/min, the CO/CO2 concentration at outlet were monitored in real-time using a Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer. The reaction rate was calculated by the formula: Reaction rate = F X V m W where F represents the reaction gases flow rate of 600 mL min-1, X is CO2 molar fraction, Vm and W represent molar volume of gas and catalyst weight, respectively. The turnover frequency (TOF) is the CO2 molecule number produced per active site, per second. The TOF values are calculated using the catalytic soot combustion reaction data at 400 °C, at which the soot conversion of both catalysts is less than 15% and the reaction is achieved in an approximate kinetic regime. Both the reactive oxygen species of O2 2- and O2- are counted as active site for TOF calculation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity Fig. 1 presents the TPC test results, all of the catalysts are tested twice to determine the catalytic activity and reproducibility. Fig. 1(a) shows the variation of CO2 concentration with temperature. CO2 production starts at about 350 °C in the presence of CeZrPrOx catalyst, while the pure soot starts to react at above 450 °C. As the temperature rises, the concentration of CO2 and the reaction rate begin to increase; subsequently, with the consumption of soot, CO2 concentration swiftly declines until soot reaches complete oxidation. The soot catalytic conversion curves of the prepared solid solution catalysts are shown in Fig. 1(b) and the peak temperature statistics are listed in Table 1 . The soot ignition temperature (T10% ) and peak temperature (TP ) of the CeZrPrOx-U are about 399 °C and 466 °C, respectively; it is definitely lower than the CeZrPrOx of 413 °C and 480 °C, respectively. The temperature when the soot conversion reaches 50% (T50% ) and 90 % (T90% ) shows the same trend. The reaction rate and TOF of the catalysts were calculated, as listed in Table 1, the reaction rate and TOF of the CeZrPrOx at 400 °C is 1.29 × 10–6 mol·s-1·g-1 and 4.11 × 10–4 s-1, respectively. For the CeZrPrOx-U catalyst, it is 2.04 × 10–6 mol·s-1·g-1 and 5.09 × 10–4 s-1, respectively. It indicates that the presence of CeZrPrOx catalyst can obviously lower the temperature of soot combustion purification, and the assisted-synthesis process of urea can significantly improve the catalytic soot purification activity of the CeZrPrOx-U. Moreover, the fresh catalysts were calcinated at 900 °C for 8 h under 7.0 vol% vapor-Air flow, and the catalytic soot combustion activity of the aged catalysts were tested to verify the stability. As shown in Fig. S2 and Table S2 in the Supporting Information, the T10%, T50% and T90% of the aged catalyst of CeZrPrOx-U-A are 405 °C, 471 °C and 507 °C, respectively. It is still obviously better than that of the CeZrPrOx-A catalyst of 410 °C, 483 °C and 523 °C. It can be seen that the superior soot catalytic combustion performance caused by the assisted-synthesis of urea can be maintained during the rigorous aging process and the CeZrPrOx-U-A catalyst has a good stability. To reveal the effects of urea assisted-synthesis strategy on catalyst structure and physical-chemical properties as well as the soot catalytic elimination activity, the prepared catalysts were systematically studied. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Morphologies SEM was used to study the microscopic morphology of the catalysts. Fig. 2(a, b) and (c, d) display the SEM photos of the CeZrPrOx and CeZrPrOx-U, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2 , the CeZrPrOx-U catalyst modified by the urea-assisted synthesis shows similar microscopic morphology with the CeZrPrOx, both of the catalysts are secondary particles consisting of irregular nanoparticle agglomerates. TEM images are presented in Fig. 3 . Both the CeZrPrOx (a, b) and CeZrPrOx-U (c, d) catalysts are composed of nanocrystal particles. It can be suggested that the microscopic morphology of the CeZrPrOx catalyst is not obviously affected by the urea-assisted synthesis process. Noteworthily, the CeZrPrOx-U appears to exhibit a higher degree of crystallinity than the CeZrPrOx. To further confirm this result, XRD analysis was employed. 3.2.2 Catalyst structural properties XRD technology was carried out to analyze the differences in crystal structure of the catalysts. The actual composition of the catalysts was determined by ICP-OES, and the results are listed in Table S1 in the Supporting Information. The actual composition of the CeZrPrOx-U and CeZrPrOx are Ce0.385Zr0.521Pr0.094Ox and Ce0.395Zr0.508Pr0.097Ox, respectively. It is similar with the theoretical composition of Ce0.4Zr0.5Pr0.1Ox. As shown in Fig. 4 , both catalysts display diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 29.1°, 33.7°, 48.5°, 57.5° and 71.0°, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), (311) and (400) planes of cubic phase Ce0.45Zr0.45Pr0.1O1.85 solid solution (ISCD 98–011–4454). The Pr characteristic peak was not observed in the neither catalyst suggesting Pr is well integrated into the crystalline cell of the CeO2-ZrO2 solid solution. The (111) crystal plane of CeZrPrOx-U and CeZrPrOx possesses full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 1.168° and 1.537°, respectively; indicating crystallite sizes of 7.0 nm and 5.4 nm, respectively. It implies that the CeZrPrOx-U has more complete crystallinity than the CeZrPrOx, this is consistent with the TEM analysis results, that may be a positive effect of the CeZrPrOx-U to maintain a good performance in catalytic soot purification process. Raman spectroscopy was used to further examine structural characteristics of the catalysts, due to the XRD patterns are too broad to conclude the phase attribution. As shown in Fig. 5 , both CeZrPrOx-U and CeZrPrOx show two strong peak signals in 300–750 cm-1 spectral region at approximately 475 cm-1 and 595 cm-1, respectively; and broad bands at higher than 800 cm-1. The F2 g stretching vibration of the CeO2 cubic fluorite structure is located at 465 cm-1 [14,29], while the introduction of Zr4+ and Pr3+ ions makes the position shift to higher values [27,31,32]. Therefore, the 475 cm-1 F2 g stretching vibration indicates the presence of the cubic fluorite structure of the ceria-zirconia-praseodymia solid solution in both prepared samples. The peak at 475 cm-1 of the CeZrPrOx-U is sharper than that of the CeZrPrOx. It is because of the grain size of the CeZrPrOx-U is larger than the CeZrPrOx, since the shape of the Raman characterization peak broadens as the particle size decreases [33], and this inference is confirmed by XRD analysis. The diffraction peaks at approximately 595 cm-1 can be attributed to the presence of tetragonal ceria-zirconia solid solution which should be a mixture of t’ and t’’ phases. The broad bands higher than 800 cm-1 (at about 834 cm-1) is assigned to the f-f transitions of lanthanide ions of Pr3+ doped ceria-zirconia lattice [34,35]. The results prove that both the prepared CeZrPrOx-U and CeZrPrOx catalysts are a mixture of cubic and tetragonal ceria-zirconia-praseodymia solid solutions. Additionally, some researches suggested that the ∼595 cm-1 signal can reflect the oxygen vacancies in CeO2 lattice [36,37], and the signal at 834 cm-1 is interpreted as O 2 2 − species [38-40]. As can be seen from Fig. 5, the 595 cm-1 and 834 cm-1 peaks of the CeZrPrOx-U are slightly stronger than that of the CeZrPrOx. It indicates the CeZrPrOx-U catalyst has more O 2 2 − and oxygen vacancies. The O 2 2 − is a typical reactive oxygen species for soot catalytic oxidation, and oxygen vacancies is also beneficial for creating reactive oxygen during the soot catalytic oxidation reaction. Thus, the urea-assisted synthesized CeZrPrOx-U catalyst should exhibit a better soot catalytic purification activity. 3.2.3 Chemical states XPS was used to quantify the difference between CeZrPrOx-U and CeZrPrOx in terms of Ce and O species. As shown in Fig. 6(a), the both catalysts exhibit ten Ce 3d characteristic peaks. The V1-V4 peaks with binding energy of about 880.7, 885.5, 899.5 and 903.8 eV are assigned to Ce3+. The U1-U6 located at 882.4, 888.8, 898.0, 901.0, 907.4 and 916.7 eV are assigned to Ce4+[25,28,41]. Ce3+/Ce4+ was derived from the proportion of the sum of total peak areas of V1-V4 to the sum of all U1-U6 peak areas. As shown in Table 2 , the Ce3+/Ce4+ of CeZrPrOx-U and CeZrPrOx are 0.30 and 0.26, respectively. The introduction of urea during catalyst synthesis process increased the Ce3+ content. Ce3+ is intimately connected to the content of oxygen vacancies, it is a crucial factor in the activation of gaseous oxygen to produce reactive oxygen species [11,42]. Moreover, the XPS Zr 3d and Pr 3d spectra of the catalysts (as shown in the Fig. S1 in Supporting Information) prove that, for the both CeZrPrOx-U and CeZrPrOx catalysts, zirconium exists in the form of Zr4+; and praseodymium exists in the form of both Pr3+ and Pr4+, because of the low atomic ratio of praseodymium (about ∼10%) in the both catalysts, the Pr 3d XPS signal noise is relatively high. XPS O1 s spectra were analyzed to determine the content of reactive oxygen species in the CeZrPrOx-U and CeZrPrOx catalysts. Three peaks at about 529.48, 531.4 and 532.5 eV are shown in the XPS O1 s spectra (Fig. 6 b) of the both catalysts, it is attributed to the presence of lattice oxygen O 2 − , chemisorbed oxygen of O 2 2 − and O 2 − , respectively [43]. The O 2 2 − and O 2 − are active oxygen species, which can enhance the soot catalytic oxidation activity [20]. The calculation results of oxygen species content are displayed in Table 2. The content of lattice oxygen for CeZrPrOx and CeZrPrOx-U are 76.8% and 70.5%, respectively. Consequently, compared to the CeZrPrOx, the CeZrPrOx-U has a greater total reactive oxygen ( O 2 2 − and O 2 − ) content, this is consistent with the Raman results. Thus, the CeZrPrOx-U with more reactive oxygen species can provide a better catalytic soot purification activity. 3.2.4 Catalyst textual properties The textual properties of the prepared solid solution catalysts were analyzed using N2 adsorption-desorption technique. The N2 adsorption-desorption and pore size distribution curves of the CeZrPrOx and CeZrPrOx-U are shown in Fig. 7 . The adsorption-desorption isotherm categories of both the CeZrPrOx and CeZrPrOx-U are type Ⅳ, indicating that the CeZrPrOx-U and CeZrPrOx had obvious mesoporous structures. At the same time, the adsorption and desorption branches of the catalyst could not completely overlap and separated to form a ring at a certain pressure range, resulting in obvious hysteresis loops due to capillary coalescence in the pore channels. The hysteresis loops of the CeZrPrOx is the H3 type suggesting typical mesoporous materials; and that of the urea-assisted synthesized CeZrPrOx-U is the mixed type of H1 and H3, that is the typical mesoporous materials have a narrow pore width distribution [14]. The CeZrPrOx processes a specific surface area of 86 m2/g with an average pore width of 7.98 nm. The CeZrPrOx-U processes a specific surface area of 67 m2/g with an average pore width of 6.16 nm. Because of the average particle size of diesel soot is generally larger than 25 nm [14,25], so the soot particle is hardly to enter into the inner pores of both the CeZrPrOx and CeZrPrOx-U. It therefore suggests that the textual properties of the prepared catalysts are not the decisive factor for diesel soot particulates catalytic purification. 3.2.5 Catalyst oxygen mobility The oxygen activation capability of the prepared solid solution catalysts were evaluated through O2-TPD. As shown in Fig. 8 , both of the catalysts present a tailed peak in the range between room temperature and 450 °C. The peak at lower than 200 °C is ascribed to the weakly chemisorbed oxygen, and the tailed peak in 250–450 °C can be attributed to oxygen species chemisorbed on oxygen vacancies [25]. In addition, the TPD signals detected at above 450 °C indicate the release of lattice oxygen [25,41]. Noteworthily, the oxygen vacancies peak at approximately 250–450 °C is strongly connected with the capability of catalyst to supply active oxygen. Thus, the CeZrPrOx-U catalyst with more oxygen vacancies would display a superior catalytic activity for diesel soot oxidation, and this conclusion fits well with the XPS results. The oxidative/reductive characteristics of the synthesized catalysts were evaluated using H2-TPR analysis. As shown in Fig. 9 , both the CeZrPrOx-U and CeZrPrOx show three connected peaks at about 300–650 °C. As is known that the pure CeO2 shows two reduction peaks at about 500 °C and 800 °C corresponding surface and bulk reduction [44]. The dopant of Zr and Pr can enhance the oxygen mobility of CeO2, and hence lower the H2-TPR peak temperature of the CeO2 catalysts. It is reported that the fresh Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 shows three reduction peaks at about 560 °C, 610 °C and 740 °C; the first one is the surface reduction, and the later twos are bulk reduction of the solid solution, the presence of two peaks for bulk reduction can be attributed to clustering of bulk oxygen vacancies [44]. Thus, the low-temperature peak signals at lower than 450 °C are caused by the catalysts surface lattice oxygen reduction, the ∼500 °C and ∼560 °C of high-temperature reduction peaks are attributed to the bulk-phase lattice oxygen reduction [45,46]. As listed in Table 3 , the low-temperature H2 consumption (Peak I) of the CeZrPrOx-U catalyst is about 0.135 mmol/g which is significantly larger than that of the CeZrPrOx of 0.084 mmol/g, although the surface area of the CeZrPrOx-U is smaller than the CeZrPrOx (67 m2/g vs. 86 m2/g). It indicates that the CeZrPrOx-U exhibits excellent oxygen mobility performance, which is conductive to the surface migration of lattice oxidation; surface lattice oxygen is the reactive oxygen for soot catalytic oxidation [31,47,48]. It thus improves the generation of surface reactive oxygen of the catalyst and enhances the soot catalytic oxidation activity. 4 Conclusions Based on the aforementioned experimental research outcomes, it can be concluded that the urea-assisted synthesis strategy is an effective approach to construct structure defects of the CeZrPrOx solid solutions, consequently improve the content of reactive oxygen species and soot catalytic elimination activity. The urea-assisted synthesis process, for the CeZrPrOx solid solutions, does not have a significant impact on morphologies and textual properties, while has a promotive effect on crystalline growth of the CeZrPrOx. Interestingly, the urea-assisted synthesis process can appreciably construct lattice defects (oxygen vacancies) and enhance oxygen migration of the CeZrPrOx solid solutions. The bulk lattice oxygen of the urea-assisted synthesized CeZrPrOx-U catalyst can be migrated to catalyst surface more easily than the conventional CeZrPrOx catalyst, and surface lattice oxygen is the reactive oxygen for soot catalytic oxidation. Therefore, the CeZrPrOx-U catalyst with more surface reactive oxygen species shows an obviously better catalytic soot purification activity than the conventional CeZrPrOx catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Creating structure defects in ceria-based solid solution catalysts is a crucial yet challenging task. Herein, urea-assisted synthesis strategy was designed for ceria-zirconia-praseodymia catalyst (CeZrPrOx) to create lattice defects; its effects on catalyst structure, physical-chemical properties and catalytic diesel soot purification activity were systematically investigated. Raman and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) findings indicate that the urea-assisted synthesized catalyst (CeZrPrOx-U) has remarkably more Ce3+ proportion (structure defects), oxygen vacancies and surface reactive oxygen species (O2 2- and O2-). Temperature-programmed reduction by hydrogen (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption by oxygen (O2-TPD) results further prove that the oxygen migration of the CeZrPrOx-U is definitely enhanced. Compared to the conventional CeZrPrOx catalyst, the bulk lattice oxygen of the CeZrPrOx-U can be migrated to the surface to generate surface reactive oxygen species more easily. As a consequence, the prepared CeZrPrOx-U catalyst exhibits obviously better catalytic diesel soot purification activity. Therefore, this study suggests that engineering the structure defects in CeZrPrOx catalyst is an effective approach to improve physical-chemical properties and enhance the soot catalytic elimination activity of the catalyst.
